BROWNSVILLE, Tenn. Hill
lizard Currin. a Negro farmer Of
700 acres, ID q new member Of
the U. S. Department Of Agri-
cultures advisory committee on
feed grams and wheat.


Mr.. Currin Is the first Of his
race to serve on this committee.
He holds BIS degree from Ten
nessee A and l State Univer-
sity.


Before taking over the 700ac
farm. he taught vocational agri-
culture for sevenyears. His farm
includes ESQ acres Of corn and
other grains, 100 acres of cotton
and ESQ acres in pasture for his
200 head Of beef cattle.

ALBANY, MY. = Justice Is
adore Bookstein of the State SUI
preme Court ruled than an order
of education commissioner ia
mes Allen for Long Island
school district to set up new
enrolment plan was discr1mi-
natory against the white pupils.


Allen had ordered the district
to end an 80 per cent Negro
student body at one school and
send them to schools in outlying
neighborhoods.

NY, JUSTICE RULES OUT


IMMIGRATION SCHOOL ORDER

NEW YORK = Pageant maya
zine this week cited Constance
Baker Motley, associate counsel,
NAACP Legal Defense Fund. az
the American to watch In the field
Of race relations In 1864.


Mrs. Motley, attorney for James
Meredith and host Of other his
toric civil rights cases. holds the
number two administrative post
at the Fund which represented
1O,485 demonstrators in 1868.


Among the distinguished cit
liens cited by Pageant are DR..
John P. Merrill, medicine, a
leader in the field of kidney trans
plantation: Rev. Malcolm Boyd,
religion, Espicopal Chaplain,
Wayne State University.


Also, Michael O. Sullivan,
theatre, star of the off-Broadway
smash, elm White America"

The NAACP had complained that
pupils In one Malverene school
we're denied equal educational OPP
portunity because they had few
associations with whites.


Bookstein cites a US. District
Court decision in support Of his
findings. The case occurred in
Indiana last year. Bookstein said
the court held that the Constitu-
tion "neither forbids racial i'm
balance nor compels racial i'm
balance"

WASHINGTON The US. SUI
preme Court ruled this week that
New Orleans must allow Negroes
to utilize its municipal audi
forum.


The victory was won by attorneys
Of the NAACP Legal Defense
Fund. APP. Tureaud and Ernest
Mortal, both Of New Orleans.


Trouble arose when Horace c..
Bynum Of the local NAACP chap
ter attempted to secure the audi
forum for a meeting.


He was denied despite the fact
that the White Citizens Councils
had been permitted to use the
facilities.

NEGROES MAY
USE LOUISIANA
CITY AUDITORIUM

WASHINGTON Families of
automobile workers in South
Bend, Ind, laid off by curtail-
ment of Studebaker operations.
are now receiving federally-do-
mated foods, the US. Department
Of Agriculture reports.


Elsewhere in the nation, more
than 100 counties and towns are
resuming food donations to needy
persons for the winter months, a
period when farm and other work.
ers are seasonally unemployed.


In Kentucky. about 1900 per-
sons in four counties we're added
to the food distribution rolls. An
other d counties across the
Nation are beginning family do
nation programs for the first
time.


These renewed efforts to wipe
out pockets Of need are in
response to President Lyndon
B. Johnson 8 request for fuller
use Of America s food abundance.
On Thanksgiving Day, Secretary
of Agriculture OrMlle L. Free
man echoed this plea in a letter
to the Governors of the so States,
requesting them to review steps
that would help include all people
in need Of their programs.

FEDERAL FOODS
SENT TO SOUTH
BEND, INDIANA

MIAMI, Fla. The famous Flori-
da A and university band, the
Marching Hundred, was the fea-
tured attraction Of the Orange
Bowl during the CHS televised
National Football League playoff
game between the Cleveland
Browns and the Green Bay Pack
ers, Sun., Jan. 5.


The incompatible 1872 piece
FAMU band we're shown over
nationwide teleNsion hoolup for
nearly 20 minutes. The telecast
included 2lO stations of the Co
lumbia Broadcasting System.


DR.. William P. Foster, band
director, put the band through
creative precision marching and
presented excellent music.

FAMU BAND THRILLED
MILLIONS ON CBS-TV
